item.title: [help] programming understanding before test
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:17, topic:220810”][quote author=zstars link=topic=289931.msg2343267#msg2343267 date=1216456639]
HURRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRR
[/quote]
iirc bloodshed uses mingw, but you can use gcc with it

i speak on behalf of myself and several other parties when i say this: stop being such a twat

note: i noticed i didnt use any capitalisation and very little punctuation, please dont cry[/quote]

Although in most contexts it is right to call mingw a compiler, if you want us to get technical, you might want to know that mingw is NOT a compiler, but a collection of tools. It includes several compilers, linkers, and other tools. The actual compiler is g++, and if you check your bin folder in your local Bloodshed Dev C++ installation folder you will probably find that there is indeed a file called precisely g++.exe. Also note that when you use mingw you are using GCC, because mingw is precisely the windows port of the GNU Compiler Collection (That is, GCC).

Please note:

All your posts in this topic have been made of the following:
a) Wrong and contextually useless information.
b) Ad-Hominem. (Refer to Wikipedia if you are not able to understand that expression).

Please also note that, personally, I find badly written posts with no content and full of (b) pathetic, rather than offensive. Though they are also fun.

Read full topic

item.title: [help] programming understanding before test
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:14, topic:220810”]hes raging because he is an idiot, Bloodshed Dev C++ is an IDE

!&()-,./?;:’" insert these where required[/quote]

Bloodshed Dev C++ is indeed an IDE. And for the person my message was intended to it makes no difference whether it is an IDE or a compiler. If you want to point out that fact it is fine, but only if you do it in a polite way and if you supply some actual wanted information with it. I know very well what a C++ compiler is, in fact, probably in a much greater depth than you. There are moments to be formally correct and there are moments to be simply helpful.

Also please note that there is no universal definition of compiler, so out of context, it is not even wrong to consider Bloodshed Dev C++ a compiler. After all, it meets the definition of compiler, understood as a Software which can produce a runnable program from source. Note also that in a Computer Sciences context, if we accept the traditional definition of compiler, a tool such as Javac (Java Compiler) wouldn’t actually be a compiler, as it doesn’t produce an executable in native binary form.

Note: If you have more offensive statements to make, please, also tell me which is the name of the compiler behind Bloodshed Dev C++. That way, at least, you will actually give some information. Thank you.

Please also note that most of the time, I act in the way I describe. That is why often, after reading an inaccurate (or even plain wrong) statement, I do not comment on it if it serves no purpose, much less make offensive comments about it or its author, even though I could.

As an example, in the post currently below this one:

stick with php a bit longer, that is basically where i started. it has excellent documentation

.net is a library… sortof

.NET is a framework, a development platform. It includes a library, but also the Runtime Environment, the .NET languages, development tools, etc. For more information, feel free to check http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_.NET#Microsoft_.NET, or the Microsoft page itself.

Read full topic

item.title: [help] programming understanding before test
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“Cain_”][quote author=zstars link=topic=289931.msg2341444#msg2341444 date=1216366426]
… If you wanna test your code, get a free compiler such as Bloodshed Dev C++.
[/quote]

i didn’t know that Bloodshed Dev C++ is a compiler :P[/quote]

Bloodshed Dev C++ as a package includes a compiler. It is in this case not significant whether Bloodshed Dev C++ is formally a compiler or not, just like it is not significant that the word “i” you are employing is not formally an English word (In English, the first person personal pronoun is the capital “I”), or that the sentence you have used is grammatically wrong (You are employing Reported Speech, so the Present Simple should become Past Simple: “I didn’t know that Bloodshed Dev C++ was a compiler”)

Read full topic

item.title: [help] programming understanding before test
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

While loops are not faster than for loops. At least, not in any self-respecting compiler.

If your language is C++, then you shouldn’t use stdlib.h or stdio.h, but cstdio and cstdlib.

To test whether the machine is big or little endian is extremely easy.

unsigned n = 1;
char * buf = reinterpret_cast<char*>(&n);
if(!buf[0]) printf("Little endian") else printf("Big endian");

In fact, it is possible to do it in two lines, but no point. Also, if you want to use C (which btw is dead and is fugly), feel free to substitute the reinterpret_cast for a C cast.

About your code, it is kinda ugly. And if it is supposed to be C++, there are indeed errors on it. If it is supposed to be plain old C, then maybe not. If you wanna test your code, get a free compiler such as Bloodshed Dev C++.

Read full topic

item.title: [help] programming understanding before test
item.dc:creator: @moparscape4lifez moparscape4lifez
item.description:
@moparscape4lifez wrote:


#include <std io.h>
#include <std lib.h>

int main(int argc, char *argv[]){

typedef unsigned char byte;  //changes unsigned char into name byte  (0..255)

int test = 0x11223344;

byte one;
byte two;
byte three;
byte four;

byte *testpointer;

testpointer = &test; //pass address of test starting to testpointer for holding

testpointer   //means the address to test starting
*testpointer  //means the value to the address of test which is (0x11223344)
&testpointer  //means the address of testpointer


so memory access by bytes lets say thats why I used a byte pointer instead of a short or int.

one = (byte*) testpointer+1;     //should be 0x11XXXXXX
two = (byte*) testpointer+2;     //should be 0xXX22XXXX
three = (byte*) testpointer+3;   //should be 0xXXXX33XX
four = (byte*) testpointer+4;    //should be 0xXXXXXX44

printf("the bytes are [%x] [%x] [%x] [%x] [%x]", one,two,three,four);

return EXIT_SUCCESS;

}

Also how do I check the endians cuz i know pcs have different memory store sortings.

correct? (I don’t have a compiler but I am doing a test for my 2nd week programming class I don’t want to make a mistake )

Also can someone tell me if any mistakes in the typing of code so i’ll know never to do that again

Also I forgot to take notes about looping… it said something about while loops are faster then for loops but I forgot why… and I think its gonna be on test as well and what should write why its faster

thanks for the help
